Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Albuterol Spray in COPD Patients Undergoing General Anesthesia

Participants.evidence: 120 smoking patients with COPD, aged 18-65 years

Intervention.evidence: randomly assigned to receive either albuterol spray (n=60) or placebo (n=60)

Objective.evidence: This study evaluated the effect of albuterol spray on hypoxia and bronchospasm in COPD patients under general anesthesia.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the occurrence of wheezing and bronchospasm, assessed perioperatively.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomization was performed using block randomization, and allocation was concealed using sequentially numbered, opaque, sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Both patients and outcome assessors were blinded.

Number_Randomised.evidence: randomly assigned to receive either albuterol spray (n=60) or placebo (n=60)

Result_Outcome.evidence: Wheezing and recurrent cough were significantly lower in the albuterol group compared to the control group (p<0.05).

Harms.evidence: No significant side effects were reported in the albuterol group.
